conclusion: To determine the electric field strength at the intersection of the diagonals of the square, we need to consider the contributions from each of the four charges.
The square has side length L. Charges +q are at points A and B. Charges -q are at points C and D. The intersection of the diagonals is the center of the square.

premise: The center of the square is equidistant from all four vertices.
conclusion: The distance from any vertex to the center is L/√2.

premise: The electric field due to a point charge q at a distance r is given by E = kq/r^2.
conclusion: For each charge, the distance to the center is L/√2, so the magnitude of the electric field due to each charge is E = 2kq/L^2.

The electric field due to +q at A points away from A towards the center. The electric field due to +q at B points away from B towards the center. The electric field due to -q at C points towards C from the center. The electric field due to -q at D points towards D from the center.

premise: Each electric field can be resolved into x and y components.
conclusion: Due to symmetry, the x-components of the fields from A and B will cancel each other, as will the y-components of the fields from C and D.

premise: The y-components of the fields from A and B will add up. The x-components of the fields from C and D will add up.
conclusion: However, due to the symmetry and equal magnitudes, these components will cancel each other out.

premise: After considering the symmetry and cancellation of components.
conclusion: The net electric field at the center of the square is zero.
